metadata.title: Beijing Trip Preparation
metadata.description: Learning Mandarin basics for an exciting trip to Beijing!

curriculum.lesson_topic: Beijing Trip Preparation: Learning Mandarin basics for an exciting trip to Beijing!

sub_topics.description: Learn how to say hello, introduce yourself, and ask basic questions to start conversations with locals.
Master essential phrases for navigating Beijing, including asking for directions, using public transportation, and taking taxis.

sub_topics.sub_topic: Dining Out: Ordering Food and Drinks
sub_topics.description: Learn how to order food and drinks in restaurants, ask about ingredients, and understand basic menu items.
Acquire the language skills needed to shop in Beijing, including asking about prices, bargaining, and making purchases.

sub_topics.sub_topic: Sightseeing: Describing and Asking About Landmarks
sub_topics.description: Learn how to describe famous landmarks, ask questions about their history, and share your experiences with others.

flashcards.example: 你好！欢迎来到北京 (Nǐ hǎo! Huānyíng lái dào Běijīng) - Hello! Welcome to Beijing.
谢谢你的帮助 (Xièxiè nǐ de bāngzhù) - Thank you for your help.
不用谢，不客气 (Búyòng xiè, bú kèqì) - No need to thank, you're welcome.
再见！祝你在北京玩得开心 (Zàijiàn! Zhù nǐ zài Běijīng wán de kāixīn) - Goodbye! Have fun in Beijing.
请问，洗手间在哪里？(Qǐngwèn, xǐshǒujiān zài nǎlǐ?) - Excuse me, where is the restroom?
是的，我想去长城 (Shì de, wǒ xiǎng qù Chángchéng) - Yes, I want to go to the Great Wall.
我不是北京人 (Wǒ bú shì Běijīng rén) - I am not from Beijing.
对不起，我听不懂 (Duìbùqǐ, wǒ tīng bù dǒng) - Sorry, I don't understand.
没关系，我可以再说一遍 (Méi guānxi, wǒ kěyǐ zàishuō yībiàn) - It's okay, I can say it again.
请问，这个多少钱？(Qǐngwèn, zhège duōshao qián?) - Excuse me, how much is this?

exercises.sentence: 你好！我___李明，很高兴认识你。
exercises.explanation: '是' (shì) means 'am' and is used to introduce oneself. '叫' (jiào) means 'called', '在' (zài) means 'at/in', and '有' (yǒu) means 'have'; none fit the context of a simple introduction.

'走' (zǒu) means 'go' or 'walk', so '怎么走' (zěnme zǒu) is the correct way to ask 'how to get to'. '说' (shuō) means 'say', '看' (kàn) means 'see', and '买' (mǎi) means 'buy', which are not suitable in asking for directions.

'住' (zhù) means 'to live' or 'to stay', which fits the context of staying in a hotel. '吃' (chī) means 'eat', '去' (qù) means 'go', and '来' (lái) means 'come', which don't make sense in the given context.

'苹果' (píngguǒ) meaning apple, is a commonly purchased item, fitting the 'how much money' question. While '椅子' (yǐzi - chair), '电脑' (diànnǎo - computer), and '书' (shū - book) can be bought, 'apple' is more typically asked about in simple price inquiries for beginners.

'对' (duì) is used with '的帮助' (de bāngzhù - help) to express 'thanks for'. The phrase '对...的帮助' (duì...de bāngzhù) translates to 'for (someone's) help'. The other options, 在 (zài - at), 是 (shì - is), and 要 (yào - want), don't fit grammatically.

simulation.title: Lost in Translation, Found in Beijing
simulation.setting: Xia Mei is preparing for her first trip to Beijing. She's eager to practice some basic Mandarin phrases she learned online to make her experience more immersive and enjoyable. This story captures a funny moment at a traditional tea house.

content.speaker: Xia Mei
content.phonetics: Nǐ hǎo! Wǒ xiǎng hē chá.
content.base_language_translation: Hello! I would like to drink tea.

content.speaker: Tea House Owner
content.phonetics: Nǐ hǎo! Qǐngwèn nín yào shénme chá?
content.base_language_translation: Hello! May I ask what kind of tea you would like?

content.speaker: Xia Mei
content.base_language_translation: I want... um... that... black tea!

content.speaker: Tea House Owner
content.phonetics: Bù kèqì. Zhè shì nín de hóngchá.
content.base_language_translation: You're welcome. This is your black tea.

content.speaker: Tea House Owner
content.base_language_translation: You're welcome. Welcome to come again!
